questions.question: Which of the following is the tumor marker associated with choriocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Beta HCG Explanation: Beta HCG is a hormone produced by the trophoblastic cells of the placenta. In gestational trophoblastic diseases, including choriocarcinoma, levels of beta HCG are significantly elevated. It is a key tumor marker for diagnosing, monitoring treatment response, and detecting recurrence in choriocarcinoma. hPL ( Option A) Elevated levels of Human placental lactogen (hPL) can be seen in Placental Site Trophoblastic Disease or Tumor. It is a hormone produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta during pregnancy and it is not a marker for choriocarcinoma. AFP ( Option C ) Alpha-fetoprotein is the tumor marker for Hepatocellular cancer and Nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. AFP is not associated with choriocarcinoma. CEA ( Option D) Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is the tumor marker for Ovarian, Colorectal, Pancreas, and Lung cancers. It is not linked with choriocarcinoma. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 241, 1169 William's Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 782 Tumor markers: A diagnostic tool - PMC Placental site trophoblastic tumor: Immunohistochemistry algorithm key to diagnosis and review of literature

questions.question: A 32 y/o woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding 18 months after her term pregnancy. Ultrasound reveals a uterine mass, and an endometrial biopsy shows intermediate trophoblastic cells. Which of the following is NOT true regarding this condition?

options.C: The preferred initial treatment is chemotherapy.
options.D: Associated with low levels of beta-hCG.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The preferred initial treatment is chemotherapy. Explanation: The given clinical scenario points towards Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT), which predominantly originates from intermediate trophoblasts at the placental site and comprises cytotrophoblastic cells. The preferred initial treatment for nonmetastatic PSTT is hysterectomy, not chemotherapy. PSTT can follow any type of pregnancy but most commonly occurs after a term gestation. (Option A) Patients typically experience irregular bleeding months or even years after a preceding pregnancy, and the diagnosis is usually considered only after an endometrial biopsy. PSTT tends to infiltrate locally within the uterus and disseminate late in its course. (Option B) It typically produces low levels of free beta-subunit of hCG, and an elevated proportion can aid in distinguishing it from other types of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. (Option D) Hysterectomy is the primary treatment for nonmetastatic PSTT due to its relative insensitivity to chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is indicated for metastatic PSTT, with regimens like EMA/EP (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D alternating with etoposide and cisplatin) considered most effective. Reference: William's Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 82

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman, G2P1, presents with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) following a molar pregnancy managed initially with suction curettage. In which of the following scenarios is hysterectomy NOT indicated for managing GTN?

options.C: GTN confined to the endometrial cavity after initial treatment.
options.D: Management of extensive metastases in GTN

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Management of extensive metastases in GTN Explanation: Hysterectomy is generally not indicated for managing extensive metastases in GTN. Metastases, especially to distant sites like the lungs, are typically managed with continued surveillance and possibly chemotherapy if recurrence or progression is detected. Hysterectomy is indicated as an emergency procedure in cases of severe, uncontrollable vaginal or intra-abdominal bleeding. (Option A) Hysterectomy may be performed as the primary treatment for chemotherapy-resistant forms of GTN, such as placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT) or epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT). (Option B) In low-risk GTN cases where future fertility is not desired, adjuvant hysterectomy may be considered. Hysterectomy may also be considered for GTN confined to the uterus. (Option C) Reference: William's Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 784

questions.question: A 34 y/o woman presents with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels following a molar pregnancy. Imaging studies reveal no evidence of metastases. What is the most appropriate initial chemotherapy regimen for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Methotrexate Explanation: This patient has low-risk Gestational trophoblastic disease, and Methotrexate (MTX) alone or in combination with folinic acid is the standard initial chemotherapy regimen. The current standard regimen: An alternating schedule of intramuscular (IM) MTX at 1 mg/kg on treatment days 1, 3, 5, and 7, combined with oral folinic acid at 15 mg on days 2, 4, 6, and 8. This cycle is repeated every 2 weeks. Alternatively, MTX can be administered daily either intravenously (IV) or intramuscularly (IM) for 5 days, with this series being repeated every 2 weeks. Risk Category Treatment Approach Low-Risk GTN Chemotherapy: Methotrexate ( MTX) alone or with folinic acid Alternative Chemotherapy: Dactinomycin for MTX-resistant cases. (Option C) High-Risk GTN Chemotherapy Regimens: EMA/CO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine). Alternative Regimens: EMA/EP (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Etoposide, Cisplatin) TP/TE (Paclitaxel, Cisplatin alternating with Paclitaxel, Etoposide) (Option A) BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin) (Option B) Reference: William's Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 785, 786

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman is being assessed for gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) using the WHO Prognostic Scoring System. Which of the following factors is NOT considered in the WHO Prognostic Scoring System for GTD? β -hCG levels
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Histological subtype of the tumor Explanation: The histological subtype of the tumor is not considered a prognostic factor in the WHO Prognostic Scoring System for GTD neoplasia. Patients who are at low risk for therapeutic failure are differentiated from those at high risk through the use of the Modified WHO Prognostic Scoring System. Modified WHO Prognostic Scoring System Factors 0 1 2 4 Age (years) <40 ≥ 40 Antecedent pregnancy Mole Abortion Term Interval (months) from index pregnancy <4 4-6 7-12 >12 Pretreatment serum β -hCG (mIU/mL) <10 3 10 3 -<10 4 10 4 -<10 5 ≥ 10 5 Largest tumor size (including the uterus) <3cm 3-4cm ≥ 5cm Site of metastases Spleen, kidney GI Liver, brain Number of metastases 1-4 5-8 >8 Previous failed chemotherapy drugs 1 ≥ 2 WHO score of 0 to 6 = Low risk WHO score of ≥ 7 = High risk Reference: William's Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 784

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Her condition is complicated by metastasis to the lungs, but no other distant sites are involved. According to the FIGO staging system, what is the appropriate stage for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stage III Explanation: Based on the FIGO anatomical staging system, Stage III is the appropriate stage for a patient with Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) and lung metastasis . FIGO anatomical staging system: Stage Defining Criteria Stage I GTN is confined to the uterus. (Option A) Stage II GTN extends to the genital structures (e.g., vagina or pelvis) but does not spread to the lungs or other distant sites. (Option B) Stage III GTN has metastasized to the lungs, with or without involvement of genital structures. Stage IV GTN has metastasized to distant sites other than the lungs (e.g., liver, brain). (Option D) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 241

questions.question: A 25 y/o woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain, an enlarged uterus, and elevated beta-hCG levels, suggesting molar pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. An Ultrasound finding of the ovaries is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Theca lutein cysts Explanation: In Molar pregnancy , ovaries may appear fuller and cystic on ultrasound due to multiple theca-lutein cysts , which are more common with complete moles. Theca Lutein Cysts: These cysts are commonly associated with molar pregnancy due to high beta-hCG levels overstimulating the ovaries. hCG and Luteinising hormone share the same receptor, stimulating the theca layer around follicles. Management : Theca-lutein cysts typically regress after pregnancy evacuation and hCG level decline, favoring expectant management. Complications : Larger cysts may occasionally undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage. Theca lutein cysts larger than 6cm in diameter are a potential risk factor for a malignant change in molar pregnancy, leading to choriocarcinoma. Functional ovarian cysts (Option A) are common and usually associated with the menstrual cycle. They do not typically present with such markedly elevated beta-hCG levels or in the context of a molar pregnancy. Endometriomas (Option B) are related to endometriosis and would not be associated with molar pregnancy. Dermoid cysts (Option C) (mature cystic

questions.question: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia can develop after any pregnancy event, but majority of cases develop after a molar pregnancy event. Which finding suggests an invasive mole rather than choriocarcinoma?

options.B: Early hematogenous spread to the lungs
options.C: Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment
options.D: HPE shows trophoblastic proliferation with villi

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Histopathological examination shows villi Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. The presence of villi in histopathological examination is typical of an invasive mole, distinguishing it from choriocarcinoma, which lacks villi, thus providing a specific diagnostic feature. Feature: Choriocarcinoma Invasive Mole Causes/Origin Often follows a term pregnancy (Option A) , miscarriage, or molar pregnancy. Less commonly associated with molar gestation. Typically, it arises from a complete hydatidiform mole. Less commonly from a partial mole. Histopathological Examination (HPE) It is composed of malignant trophoblastic cells resembling early cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast. Contains no villi. Presence of both cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast cells. Shows trophoblastic proliferation with hydropic villi. Invasion/Metastasis Rapid growth with early hematogenous spread. Common metastasis sites: lungs (Option B ), vagina, liver, brain, kidneys. Locally invasive into the myometrium. It rarely metastasises but can spread to the lungs if it does. Management Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment (Option C). Surgery (e.g., hysterectomy) considered. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 242

questions.question: A 30 y/o woman presents with persistent vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain following a recent molar pregnancy. O/E, her uterus is enlarged and tender. She has markedly elevated serum beta HCG levels. Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in metastasis of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lungs Explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of choriocarcinoma, in which the lungs are the most common site of metastasis. Patients often present with "cannonball" metastases, which are multiple, large, round opacities seen in the lungs on chest X-rays. The most common route of metastasis is Hematogenous. The most common sites of metastasis are the lungs and vagina; however, tumors can also spread to other areas such as the vulva, kidneys, liver, brain, ovaries, and bowel. Bone (Option A) While bone metastasis can occur in various types of cancers, it is the rare site for metastasis of choriocarcinoma. Kidney (Option B) Choriocarcinoma can metastasize to the kidneys, but it is not the most common site. Liver (Option C) Choriocarcinoma can metastasize to the Liver secondary to hematogenous dissemination, but it is not the most common site. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 242

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding and a positive pregnancy test. Her serum β -hCG level is 180,000 mIU/mL. Which of the following benign gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTD) is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hydatidiform Mole. Explanation: Hydatidiform mole is classified as a benign form of GTD and is characterized by abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue in the uterus. This results in swollen, fluid-filled villi and significantly elevated β -hCG levels (often in the range of 100,000 mIU/mL or higher). Initially benign, they can sometimes progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (Option B) PSTTs are considered malignant due to their potential for deep myometrial invasion and metastasis. They arise from intermediate trophoblasts at the placental implantation site. They present with slightly elevated β -hCG levels, but not as high as seen in hydatidiform moles. Choriocarcinoma (Option C) Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant gestational trophoblastic disease that can follow any type of pregnancy event and is characterized by extremely high β -hCG levels and significant potential for rapid spread and metastasis. Epithelial Trophoblastic Tumor (Option D) Epithelial trophoblastic tumors are malignant and arise from chorionic-type intermediate trophoblast. They have low β -hCG levels. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 235,236,242

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of choriocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hydatidiform mole Explanation: The most common precursor of Choriocarcinoma, a form of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, is the hydatidiform mole (complete), accounting for approximately half of all cases of choriocarcinoma. Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant neoplasm derived from the chorionic epithelium, exhibiting aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium. It lacks the formation of villous structures. Risk factors for choriocarcinoma 50 % of cases follow after Hydatidiform mole 30 % of cases follow miscarriage or ectopic pregnancy (Option A & B) 20 % of cases follow preterm pregnancy or term pregnancy (Option D) Trophoblastic disease after a normal pregnancy can either be choriocarcinoma or placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), rather than a benign or invasive mole. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page781

questions.question: Which of the following is not a laboratory criterion for diagnosing post-molar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia? A. β -hCG levels plateau for at least 3 weeks. β -hCG levels increase by more than 10% over three consecutive weekly measurements. β -hCG level after 6 months of evacuation.

options.C: Elevation of carcinoembryonic antigen in the serum over 3 weeks.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Elevation of carcinoembryonic antigen in the serum over 3 weeks. Explanation: Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA) elevation is associated with ovarian malignancies and not with gestational trophoblastic disease; thus, it is not a characteristic criterion for diagnosing post-molar GTN. The criteria for diagnosing post-molar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia are: β -hCG levels plateau for at least 3 weeks, with no significant change in measurements taken on days 1, 7, 14, and 21 post-evacuation. (Option A) Serum β -hCG levels increase by more than 10% over three consecutive weekly measurements, spanning at least 2 weeks, starting from days 1, 7, and 14 post-evacuation. (Option B) Detectable serum β -hCG level after 6 months of evacuation (Option D) Histological criteria for choriocarcinoma. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page241, 1169

questions.question: After the evacuation of molar pregnancy, effective contraception is necessary to avoid confusion between pregnancy and persistent gestational trophoblastic disease. Which of the following should not be used as a contraceptive until the serum beta HCG has normalized?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Intrauterine device Explanation: Using an intrauterine device should be avoided until the serum beta HCG returns to normal because there is a risk of uterine perforation if an invasive mole is present. Recommended contraceptive methods Combined oral contraceptive pills: Most preferred (Option A) Depot Medroxyprogesterone Acetate (Injectable) (Option C) Progestin Implants (Option D) IUD is contraindicated due to the risk of uterine perforation if an invasive mole is present. It is advised to avoid conception for up to 12 months. But If Pregnancy is desired, may conceive 6 months after serum beta HCG normalization. Delay pregnancy for 1 year after gestational trophoblastic neoplasia and 2 years if metastasis is present. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 240

questions.question: A 28 y/o gravid patient came to the OPD after passing grape-like clusters of vesicles from her vagina. USG and HPE of the tissue confirmed a molar pregnancy. She underwent suction and evacuation, with weekly serum beta HCG tests until they returned to normal. How long should monthly beta HCG tests continue to exclude persistent trophoblastic disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 6 months Explanation: Monthly beta HCG levels should be estimated up to 6 months after molar pregnancy evacuation to exclude persistent trophoblastic disease. β -hCG Monitoring : The initial test is within 48 hours post-evacuation for baseline. (Option A) Follow-up every 1-2 weeks until normalization. Post-Normalization Testing: Monthly β -hCG tests for another 6 months. Median Resolution Time for GTD : Partial moles: 6 weeks. Complete moles: 7 weeks. Normalisation Timeline of beta HCG levels: 95% by 14 weeks. 99% by 25 weeks Evaluation for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is required if β -hCG levels increase or plateau. 9 & 12 months (Option C & D): The testing is continued monthly for only 6 more months post evacuation after β -hCG are undetectable.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 10 weeks of gestation. β -hCG levels are elevated. What is the gold standard investigation for confirming the diagnosis of molar pregnancy? β -hCG levels
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Histopathological examination (HPE). Explanation: Histopathological examination (HPE) provides definitive diagnosis and differentiation between complete and partial moles. It allows for detailed examination of tissue architecture and cellular characteristics, essential for accurate classification and determining the risk of persistent trophoblastic disease. Histopathological findings include: Partial Mole Complete Mole Focal villous edema (some villi are normal, others are edematous) Presence of fetal blood vessels in some villi. Focal trophoblastic hyperplasia Presence of fetal tissue (may include fetal red blood cells or embryonic/fetal parts). Diffuse villous edema and hydropic swelling. Absence of fetal blood vessels in villi Marked atypical trophoblastic hyperplasia (both cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast). No fetal tissue is present. Ultrasonography (USG) (Option B) is the initial choice of investigation for molar pregnancies but is not confirmatory as it may mimic missed abortions sometimes Partial mole ultrasound shows mixed echogenicity with focal cysts, possible fetal parts or sacs, thick multicystic placenta, and, if present, an abnormal or growth-restricted fetus. Complete moles reveal a classic "snowstorm" appearance with numerous small cysts, no fetal parts, possibly theca lutein ovarian cysts, and increased vascularity on Doppler. Serum β -hCG levels (Option C) are elevated in both molar and normal pregnancies and cannot definitively diagnose molar pregnancy alone. CT and MRI (Option D) Routine use of CT and MRI is not recommended for diagnosis during pregnancy . Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 236,238, 239

questions.question: A 30 y/o woman presents at 12 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound shows a heterogeneous mass filling the uterine cavity with multiple small cystic spaces, creating a "snowstorm" appearance. No fetal parts are visible. Which of the following is the most common initial finding in a complete molar pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bleeding per vagina Explanation: Bleeding per vagina is the most common initial clinical presentation of complete molar pregnancy. Feature Complete Molar Pregnancy Partial Molar Pregnancy Vaginal Bleeding Most common (80-90%), are dark and intermittent. Less prominent; Often present like missed abortion (Option A) Uterine Size Often larger than expected Appropriate or slightly smaller (Option D) Hyperemesis Gravidarum Common, due to high hCG levels Less common Hyperthyroidism This can occur due to hCG/TSH similarity Rare Products of Conception Complete molar tissue (Grape-like vesicles), characteristic of complete mole Less advanced hydatiform changes hCG Levels Extremely high (>1,00,000 mIU/mL) Lower than the complete mole (<1,00,000 mIU/mL) (Option B) Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 236-238

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound shows the following appearance in the uterus. Which karyotype result is most consistent with a complete molar pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 46, XY. Explanation: Complete molar pregnancies typically have a karyotype of 46, XY, or 46, XX (diploid). Feature Partial Mole Complete Mole Karyotype Usually 69, XXY or 69, XXX (triploid) (Option A, C) Usually 46, XX or 46, XY (diploid) Genetic origin 2 paternal sets + 1 maternal set All paternal (empty egg + sperm duplication) Fetal tissue It may be present but abnormal. Absent. β -hCG levels Elevated, but lower than the complete mole Very high Risk of persistent GTD 5-10% 15-20% Risk of choriocarcinoma 2-4% 2-3% Theca lutein cysts Less common Common Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page 237, 238

questions.question: Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for developing Gestational Trophoblastic Disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Previous history of molar pregnancy Explanation: Women who have had a previous molar pregnancy have a significantly increased risk of developing another molar pregnancy or other forms of GTD in subsequent pregnancies. Risk Factors of GTD: Ethnic predisposition: Higher prevalence in Asians, Hispanics, and American Indians Strongest risk factors: Maternal age (both extremes of reproductive age) Prior history of hydatidiform mole Risk after previous molar pregnancies: After one complete mole: 0.9% risk of another mole. After one partial mole: 0.3% risk of another mole. After two complete moles: 20% risk of a third mole. Maternal age below 35 years (Option A): Maternal age is a risk factor for GTD, but the highest risk is typically associated with maternal age at the extremes (below 20 years or above 35 years). Use of oral contraceptives (Option C) is not a risk factor for molar pregnancy Ethnicity (Asian or African descent) (Option D): While ethnicity can increase the risk, it is not as strong a risk factor as a previous history of molar pregnancy. The recurrence of GTD is much more closely linked to personal medical history rather than ethnicity alone. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page237
